question: What is achalasia?
ideal_answer: Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by aperistalsis of the esophagus and failed relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter that presents rarely in childhood.

snippets.text: Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by aperistalsis of the esophagus and failed relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter that presents rarely in childhood.
Idiopathic achalasia is a rare esophageal motor disorder.
The pathophysiology of achalasia is largely unknown, and involves the destruction of ganglion cell in the esophageal myenteric plexus.

BACKGROUND
Idiopathic achalasia is a rare motor disorder of the oesophagus characterised by neuronal loss at the lower oesophageal sphincter.
Achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by total loss of esophageal peristalsis and by defective lower esophageal sphincter function.

BACKGROUND
Achalasia is defined manometrically by an aperistaltic esophagus.
Achalasia is one of the most studied esophageal motility disorders.

BACKGROUND & AIMS
Idiopathic achalasia is a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by incomplete relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and a loss of normal peristaltic activity in the body of the esophagus.
Achalasia is a disorder characterized by abnormal motility of the esophageal body and the lower esophageal sphincter, resulting in dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain.
Achalasia is a chronic incurable esophageal motility disorder characterized by impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation and loss of esophageal peristalsis.
Achalasia is a rare esophageal motility disorder, characterized by its distinct motility pattern with absent or incomplete lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxations.
Achalasia is an infrequent primary motility disorder of the esophagus.
